Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Gusts to moderate. Moderate to high W to SW winds off the Dana Plateau. Visible snow transport down into the gullies on E. Peak of Dana, Coke- and Ripper Chutes. Did not see any evidence of natural avalanches during the weekend storm. Active wind loading ATL and NTL the whole time we were out until 1530. The snow BTL was mostly unaffected by the winds. Most evidence of instability was observed in the top 10 to 15 cm of the snowpack. Kick tests propagated and the soft wind slab broke into blocks.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope
Collapsing, localized; Cracking
Collapsing, localized; Instability rapidly rising
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent activity on similar slopes; Instability rapidly rising; Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Clear conditions for most of the morning, temperatures ranging from 22 degrees Fahrenheit at 10,200ft, and 17 degrees Fahrenheit at and above 11,000ft. Winds blowing from the West at 15-20mph, gusts near 30mph on N/NE/E aspects. Temperatures slowly warmed to 23 degrees above treeline, with thin cirrostratus and small lenticular clouds forming to the southeast by 1200; visibility was not affected.

This pit was dug nearby the fatal avalanche that happened on Feb 9. We wanted to see what the snowpack looked like if we were assessing the snowpack in that area and had not seen this avalanche. Boot penetration was mostly to the top of the 1F slab. However, every other step would basically punch through to facets below the slab.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile of remotely triggered, fatal avalanche. This was just below several trees and not a perfect location. Hardness of some layers may not be representative but the snow depths seemed very representative of where the slide was triggerd. It was hard to find a safe location to look at the crown. Parts of the crown near the ridge were heavily wind loaded
Will have to keep track of the snow near the rain crust, especially around this elevation and higher as the crust thins.
Calm Sunny day but cool not much if any solar sheding or loose wet like one would have thought

Sheltered with less evidence of wind affect here than most other places in Croy. New storm snow over past 4 days bonded well to crust. Basal layers moist and rounding but still exhibiting propensity for propagation. Cross slope PST 20/100 (end) under ice layer at 19.5 up from ground. No cracking or collapsing noted, stability good on non-windloaded slopes of this aspect under 30*

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area
We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Flurries, graupel, open sky all within 40 minutes. Crust complex (20190120 rain crust and MF crusts) at 140-170 contain multiple bands of harder and less hard layers. Most P or harder, but some looser grains at interfaces. With Northstar ski patrol.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Both flurries and some clear sky during measurements. Crust complex (20190120 rain crust and MF crusts) at 140-170 contain multiple bands of harder and less hard layers, most P or harder. Some loose grains at crust boundaries. With Northstar ski patrol.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The layer of buried surface hoar was clearly visible on the pit wall. It was about 0.5cm thick, but I created an entire layer for it because my CTs failed on that layer. The surface hoar crystals appeared to be rounding, but I was unsure if that was due to air temperatures while exposed. I gave it a F hardness, but it was tough to descern.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug along old crown line from human triggered avalanche that occurred on Jan 18. Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Profil strax ovanför brottkant på 3-4 dygn gammal Na2. Lavinen har troligen startat i FC på MFcr 4 jan och snabbt stegat ner till djupare facettlager, nära marksläpp. Förhållandevis stabila testresultat, kan bero på att de svaga lagren redan hade kollapsat och sintrat ihop./Johan

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: HMH SRSC Recon. No Cracking, Collapsing, Whoomphing. Similar slope was controlled with explosive with no results.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Travelled through areas of well-developed surface hoar as well as wind loading, just not at this site. Punchy skiing, pole plants to the ground. Did not venture onto steeper terrain. Solar aspects much thinner with 5cm breakable MF crust. Cross-slope PST 30/100 (end) down 35 at top of depth hoar layer. LyteProbe testing mission.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Full data Pit for Level 1 class on SW facing aspect after several days of High winds at 12000'. Well developed basal faceting with strong overlying snowpack. Variable conditions, we did ski 7 Meadows.
Surface form SH 1.5-3.0 mm, T20 -4.5 degC
Dug down to 90cm

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit dug in a Ski Area
Collapsing, widespread; Collapsing, localized
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We observed many, widespread whumphs on E aspects above 7400' that propagated hundreds of feet and were audible from several hundred feet away. Solar aspects heated up mid-day; we observed water dripping from the trees and the snow surface was either damp or sun-crusted.
Tree line elevation on Corn Biscuit, bench feature, test profile down 1 meter.
Pit dug above convex roll in slope. All crusts cut in isolation... test results a bit inconsistent.

Pit location selected in area with greatest suspicion of instability. NNW facing, moderate snowpack depth, mild wind affect. Hoped to demonstrate instability of persistent weak layers at the ground, and evaluate stability of recent storm events. Was able to identify a thin faceted layer (suspect near surface facets) below strong layers from recent storm events and wind transport. ECT without result during loading steps. Manipulation of column did allow for a clean fracture between two strong layers near surface of different density related to different storm events.
Overall no signs of instability on tour. Warm days and cold nights have added strength to the snowpack and interfaces are continuing to gain strength.
Snowpit Video https://drive.google.com/file/d/1oLRroHzv2tnC1w_cuzu6ZcygIkyDeJdW/view?usp=sharing
Probed to 390cm below surface and did not hit ground.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Collapsing and cracking on the way up. Snowpack is still relatively thin/weak up here.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Significant collapsing on S aspect above hut @ 11750', likewise collapsing on SE aspects at 11000' and 11400. ECT only propagated 40cm @22 taps from shoulder. Dug at top of slope, found no significant slab, skied 28-31 degrees with caution, glad we had fat skis.
Well protected treed area BTL

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Gryfjan er tekin ofan við endastöð bungulyftu og sýnir góðan stöðuleika. Fáum metrum norðar í sömu hæð brotnar þekjan á 30cm dýpi í samþjöppunarprófi á 11 höggum, sýnir að víða er stöðuleikin ekki eins.
Looking for Dec 26th surface hoar layer.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: wind blowing through trees, depositing on surface, filling in tracks and depressions but not forming a crust currently. first few clear days since a little over a stormy week with heavy PI, big HST and strong winds contributing to transport. Large avalanches widespread, mostly triggered with explosives in wind loaded areas, seeing signs of PWL being overloaded as many of the slides are failing at/near the ground.

Two tests, 1/26 and 1/27, same time of day within 100' of eachother. Pits on 1/26 showed CT tests easily but no ECT reaction. On 1/27 was able to get week layer near surface to react, and positive reaction on PST showing PWL still present and bridge not fully there. Pits located below ridgeline sheltered trees.
Ngt snödrev

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Majority of this snow pack composed of two storms, Jan 6 and Jan 17 2019. Even one week after most recent load, observing widespread continual cracking and collapsing en route. Feels like early-season snow pack.
Dug pit with Dave Fandrich at the YC south study plot outside the south boundary.

Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Testing Jan 17th SH and Oct. MFcr/FH

Obvious weak layer (DH) at 45 cm, but unable to effect this relatively deep layer via ECT (even when pounded). The tall (120 cm) column failed easily on this week layer when pried with a shovel (Q3-).
No obvious signs of instability in this area of lower slope angles, deeper pack, and absence of wind loading. No props on ect's, but planar test results on basal layer still concerning.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Easy hand shears later in the day, whumphing increased in the afternoon as the falling snow was warmer and wetter.
